title: Is Siberia really mostly a wasteland? - Quora

response.answer_text: Define “wasteland”. If you thought about something like this(from Google results to “wasteland” query):  Or, probably, like this (that’s “frozen wasteland” by Google):  Then no. Most places of Siberia are occupied by forest(mostly coniferous forest). It’s the largest forest on the planet, Amazonia is only the second after it. This forest has its own name: Taiga. It looks like that in summer:   And like that in winter:   It doesn’t look like the wasteland from above, does it? On the other hand, Taiga is a “wasteland” in the meaning that it is mostly uninhabited by humans, you can literally walk hundreds or even thousands of kilometers in it and never meet another human. But don’t try that at home, kids. Taiga is inhabited by many nasty creatures, like these:      Again, doesn’t look like wasteland to me. Update: Okay, Vyacheslav Vvedenskiy pointed out that these creatures, which also live in Taiga, are actually much nastier:    And you know… I tend to agree.

Depends what one defines as a ‘wasteland’. Just because most of Siberia is frozen over half the year and much of it has permafrost, doesn't necessarily make it a wasteland. Siberia is rich in natural resources but the vastness, terrain and climate make it a challenge to get to. Siberia is similar to northern Canada and northern Alaska. But parts of these areas have been developed. If those areas can do it so can Siberia. It already contains large cities and the longest rail system for such a high latitude. So no Siberia isn't a wasteland.
